quizzes.question: According to the box model, every element on a web page is a:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]More on Box Models[/h1]

Every element of the webpage is a [b]box[/b]. 

CSS uses the box model to determine how big the boxes are and how to place them.
[note]The box model is also used to calculate the actual width and height of the HTML elements.[/note]

quizzes.question: The background color of the content also covers:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Total Width of an Element[/h1]

When working with boxes, it is important to understand how the total width of an element is calculated. 
For example, the total width of the box with paddings will be the sum of [b]width[/b] plus [b]padding left[/b] and [b]padding right[/b].[img id="2999" width="100%"]   
Here is another box with margins, border, and paddings. 
The total width is the sum of [b]left and right margins[/b], [b]left and right borders[/b], [b]left and right paddings[/b], and the [b]actual width[/b] of the content.[img id="3013" width="100%"]  
[note]When you set the width and height properties of an element with CSS, you set the width and height of the content area.
When setting a background-color to a box, it covers the content area, as well as the padding.[/note]

quizzes.question: Enter the total width of an element in pixels, if its width=150px, left and right paddings=5px each, border width=2px and left and right margins=5px each.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Total Height of an Element[/h1]

The total height of an element is calculated the same way as the width. 
The example below is the same box from the previous lesson with padding, border and margin.[img id="3014" width="100%"]   
[note]To summarize, Total element height = height + top padding + bottom padding + top border + bottom border + top margin + bottom margin[/note]
